title: Outcome Measure Report: Association of Bariatric Surgery vs Medical Obesity Treatment With Long-term Medical Complications and Obesity-Related Comorbidities (2018 Norwegian Cohort)

extension.valueMarkdown: This example of an OutcomeMeasureReport Profile shows a report from a single observational study with 4 outcome measures.

text.div:
Risk of Remission of diabetes in control group was 14.8%. Risk of Remission of diabetes in intervention group was 57.5%. Greater likelihood of diabetes remission: AR, 57.5% vs 14.8%; RD, 42.7% [95% CI, 35.8%-49.7%], RR, 3.9 [95% CI, 2.8-5.4]
Compared with specialized medical treatment, bariatric surgery appears to induce remission of diabetes.
Risk of Remission of diabetes in control group was 14.8%.

entry.display: ComparatorOnlyEvidence: Remission of diabetes without bariatric surgery (Control Group) in JAMA 2018 Norwegian cohort study

text.div: Risk of Remission of diabetes in intervention group was 57.5%.

entry.display: InterventionOnlyEvidence: Remission of diabetes with bariatric surgery (Intervention Group) in JAMA 2018 Norwegian cohort study

text.div: [No data.]

Greater likelihood of diabetes remission: AR, 57.5% vs 14.8%; RD, 42.7% [95% CI, 35.8%-49.7%], RR, 3.9 [95% CI, 2.8-5.4]
Compared with specialized medical treatment, bariatric surgery appears to induce remission of diabetes.

entry.display: ComparativeEvidence: Bypass surgery effects on Remission of diabetes in JAMA 2018 Norwegian cohort study

text.div:
Risk of New onset depression in control group was 6.5%. Risk of New onset depression in intervention group was 8.9%. Greater risk of new-onset depression: AR, 8.9% vs 6.5%; RD, 2.4% [95% CI, 1.3%-3.5%], RR, 1.5 [95% CI, 1.4-1.7].
Compared with specialized medical treatment, bariatric surgery may slightly increase the incidence of depression.
Risk of New onset depression in control group was 6.5%.

entry.display: ComparatorOnlyEvidence: New onset depression without bariatric surgery (Control Group) in JAMA 2018 Norwegian cohort study

text.div: Risk of New onset depression in intervention group was 8.9%.

entry.display: InterventionOnlyEvidence: New onset depression with bariatric surgery (Intervention Group) in JAMA 2018 Norwegian cohort study

text.div: [No data.]

Greater risk of new-onset depression: AR, 8.9% vs 6.5%; RD, 2.4% [95% CI, 1.3%-3.5%], RR, 1.5 [95% CI, 1.4-1.7].
Compared with specialized medical treatment, bariatric surgery may slightly increase the incidence of depression.

entry.display: ComparativeEvidence: Bypass surgery effects on New onset depression in JAMA 2018 Norwegian cohort study

text.div:
Risk of Treatment with opioids in control group was 15.8%. Risk of Treatment with opioids in intervention group was 19.4%. Greater risk of treatment with opioids: AR, 19.4% vs 15.8%, RD, 3.6% [95% CI, 2.3%-4.9%], RR, 1.3 [95% CI, 1.2-1.4].
Compared with specialized medical treatment, bariatric surgery may slightly increase the use of opioids.
Risk of Treatment with opioids in control group was 15.8%.

entry.display: ComparatorOnlyEvidence: Treatment with opioids without bariatric surgery (Control Group) in JAMA 2018 Norwegian cohort study

text.div: Risk of Treatment with opioids in intervention group was 19.4%.

entry.display: InterventionOnlyEvidence: Treatment with opioids with bariatric surgery (Intervention Group) in JAMA 2018 Norwegian cohort study

text.div: [No data.]

Greater risk of treatment with opioids: AR, 19.4% vs 15.8%, RD, 3.6% [95% CI, 2.3%-4.9%], RR, 1.3 [95% CI, 1.2-1.4].
Compared with specialized medical treatment, bariatric surgery may slightly increase the use of opioids.

entry.display: ComparativeEvidence: Bypass surgery effects on Treatment with opioids in JAMA 2018 Norwegian cohort study

text.div:
Risk of additional GI surgical procedure in control group was 15.5%. Risk of additional GI surgical procedure in intervention group was 31.3%. Surgical patients had a greater risk for undergoing at least 1 additional gastrointestinal surgical procedure (AR, 31.3% vs 15.5%; RD, 15.8% [95% CI, 13.1%-18.5%]; RR, 2.0 [95% CI, 1.7-2.4]).
Compared with specialized medical treatment, bariatric surgery appears to increase the rate of additional gastrointestinal surgical procedures.
Risk of additional GI surgical procedure in control group was 15.5%.

entry.display: ComparatorOnlyEvidence: Additional GI surgical procedure without bariatric surgery (Control Group) in JAMA 2018 Norwegian cohort study

text.div: Risk of additional GI surgical procedure in intervention group was 31.3%. 292 out of 932 observed with percentage of: 31.3%

entry.display: InterventionOnlyEvidence: Additional GI surgical procedure with bariatric surgery (Intervention Group) in JAMA 2018 Norwegian cohort study

text.div: [No data.]

Surgical patients had a greater risk for undergoing at least 1 additional gastrointestinal surgical procedure (AR, 31.3% vs 15.5%; RD, 15.8% [95% CI, 13.1%-18.5%]; RR, 2.0 [95% CI, 1.7-2.4]).
Compared with specialized medical treatment, bariatric surgery appears to increase the rate of additional gastrointestinal surgical procedures.
